Reinhard Selten

Reinhard Selten (1930-2016) was a renowned German economist who made significant contributions to the field of game theory and economics. Throughout his illustrious career, Selten was recognized for his groundbreaking work, earning him numerous accolades and memberships in prestigious academic organizations. Membership in the American Mathematical Society

One of the notable affiliations of Reinhard Selten was his membership in the American Mathematical Society (AMS). This esteemed organization, founded in 1888, is dedicated to promoting mathematical research and education. Studies and References

Selten's association with the AMS can be traced back to the 1960s, when he began to explore the applications of mathematical models in economics. His seminal work, "An Economic Theory of Games" (1965), co-authored with John Harsanyi, laid the foundation for the development of game theory in economics. [1] This pioneering research caught the attention of the AMS, which recognized the significance of Selten's contributions to the field of mathematics. In 1970, Selten was invited to deliver a lecture at the AMS Summer Meeting, where he presented his paper, "Mathematical Models of Oligopolistic Competition" [2]. This presentation solidified his reputation as a leading expert in the application of mathematical models to economic problems. Further evidence of Selten's membership in the AMS can be found in the society's publication, the Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society. In 1975, the bulletin featured an article by Selten, titled "On the Stability of Nash Equilibria" [3], which explored the mathematical foundations of game theory. Awards and Recognition
